name: Malayan Peacock-Pheasant
description: Its brownish feathers are adorned with numerous green eye-spots on the back and wings, which in males are large and beige-edged. Males have an orange facial wattled area around the eyes, females a yellowish one. The black crest on the crown is larger in males than in females.
food_note: Mainly invertebrates, also seeds, fruits, and other plant parts
image_alt: Malayan peacock-pheasant, photo: Prague Zoo archive
proportions: Body length 40–53.5 cm; tail length of males 24–25 cm; weight 0.58–0.68 kg
reproduction: According to breeding data, females lay 1 large egg, incubating it for 22–23 days.
attractions: Little is known about its life in the wild. It is likely polygamous, like most pheasants. The male, occupying a territory of up to 60 hectares, clears a spot on the forest floor during courtship and attracts females with a distinctive call, followed by a complex ritualized dance.
projects_note: Only a few localities remain from its original range where it survives. It is thus classified as a vulnerable species.
breeding: The first pair arrived in 1992 from Chleby Zoo and lived in Prague for ten years. The first chicks were raised in 1995, and the breeding tradition continues uninterrupted to the present. In 2012, two chicks, numbered 57 and 58, were successfully raised, one of which still lives at the zoo.
